title:
Effect of high pressure synthesis conditions on the formation of high
  entropy oxides
authors:
Solveig Stubmo Aamlid, Minu Kim, Mario U. Gonz\'alez-Rivas, Mohamed
  Oudah, Hidenori Takagi, Alannah M. Hallas
abstract:
High entropy materials are often entropy stabilized, meaning that the
configurational entropy from multiple elements sharing a single lattice site
stabilizes the structure. In this work, we study how high-pressure synthesis
conditions can stabilize or destabilize a high entropy oxide (HEO). We study
the high-pressure and high-temperature phase equilibria of two well-known
families of HEOs: the rock-salt structured compound (Mg,Co,Ni,Cu,Zn)O including
some cation substitutions and the spinel structured (Cr,Mn,Fe,Co,Ni)$_3$O$_4$.
Syntheses were performed at various temperatures, pressures, and oxygen
activity levels resulting in dramatically different synthesis outcomes. In
particular, in the rock salt HEO we observe the competing tenorite and wurtzite
phases and the possible formation of a layered rock salt phase, while the
spinel HEO is highly susceptible to decomposition into a mixture of rock-salt
and corundum phases. At the highest tested pressures, 15 GPa, we discover the
transformation of the spinel HEO into a metastable modified ludwigite-type
structure with nominal formula (Cr,Mn,Fe,Co,Ni)$_4$O$_5$. The relationship
between the synthesis conditions and the final reaction product is not
straightforward. Nonetheless, we conclude that high-pressure conditions provide
an important opportunity to synthesize high entropy phases that cannot be
formed any other way.
subjects: Condensed Matter/Disordered Systems and Neural Networks
